urn:contentItem:6GKM-BNV3-RS5Y-606M-00000-00Fires in Castilla y León keep 18 towns evacuated and advance towards Cantabria2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisFires in Castilla y León keep 18 towns evacuated and advance towards Cantabria


The weather conditions that fanned the flames in Castilla y León on Monday have added eight new evacuations caused by the fires in La Baña, Garaño and Fasgar-Igüeña, reaching 18 towns.
The delegate of the Junta in León, Eduardo Diego, has highlighted, after the meeting of the Integrated Operational Coordination Center (CECOPI), that León maintains only three fires with danger level 2 for threatening populations, after the good evolution of the fire of Molinaseca, which is already without flame and has been downgraded to level 0.


This improvement has allowed the residents of Molinaseca and Lombillos to return to their homes.
Good news that does not hide that the de-escalation in the eviction of localities for being threatened by the flames has been broken, due to the fires of La Baña, where the virulence of the flames has made it impossible to control the perimeter and has caused the eviction of the localities of Losadilla, Forna, Santa Eulalia de Cabrera, Trabazos, Encinedo and Castrohinojo.
Related to this topicHigh temperatures rekindle fires in Zamora and León, and force new evacuations
In this fire the attempts of the extinguishing operation to prevent the advance of the front advancing towards Losadilla through technical fires has failed due to the strong and changing gusts of winds so it has been decided to evacuate the localities mentioned, explained the delegate of the Board.
On the other hand, the Garaño fire that started last Sunday has evacuated two new towns: Mora de Luna and Vega de Caballeros, with a total of 90 people evacuated.
This fire, whose probable cause under investigation is that it has been intentionally provoked, already kept evicted since yesterday the towns of Viñayo, Piedrasecha, Portilla de Luna and Següera de Lunas with a total of more than 180 people evacuated.
The fire currently has two fronts, the first between the towns of Garaño and Portilla de Luna, and about four kilometers of perimeter, where he has worked throughout the day with ground and air resources.
Related to this subjectThe Council of Ministers approves this Tuesday the emergency zone for the territories affected by the fires
"In this case the flames have behaved in a convective way by the action of the wind, so its control has been very complicated, the forecast is that at night when weather conditions improve can attack the flames," said Diego.
The last fire of level 2 of danger is that of Fasgar-Igueña, two fires that started independently and that have been united having the same technical direction and where evacuated populations are also maintained.
Related to this topicFirefighters continue to fight 12 large active fires, with special concern in León
In this fire there are three active fronts, one heading towards Vegapujín and Fasgar and another one towards the town of Colinas de Martín Moro.
There is still a lot of flames in a fire that has a large perimeter, to which is added the steep terrain so that throughout the day has been trying to contain the flames with aerial means.
The third active front is the one located in the south and is directed to Tremor, where also the complexity of the terrain, very rocky, makes it difficult to extinguish the fire, so it is being left to evolve the flames towards an old mining open pit to try to extinguish the fire there directly.
Related to this topicTwo new fires worsen the situation in Castilla y León, which has eleven serious fires
Eduardo Diego wanted to thank the work of all firefighting operations, which have worked up to 42 aerial means, 36 bulldozers, 35 fire engines, 38 crews of the Junta de Castilla y León, means that have joined numerous troops of the Military Emergency Unit (UME), other autonomous communities and France.
The fire advances towards Cantabria
The Cantabrian municipality of Hermandad de Campoo de Suso is being affected by a forest fire that comes from one that has been reactivated in the Palencia town of Brañosera, in whose extinction are working forest firefighters from Cantabria and Castilla y León.
This is the only active fire in the autonomous community, after this Tuesday has been extinguished another that started yesterday in the municipality of Valderredible, as reported by the regional government.
Related to this topicThe wave of fires fuels in the fachosphere the hoaxes that nurture the denialist narrative of climate emergency
Juan Oliver

Cantabria maintains the pre-emergency situation of the Territorial Emergency Plan of Cantabria to continue collaborating with the rest of the autonomous communities in the fight against fires.
As in previous days, Cantabrian forest firefighters also continue to support the work of controlling the hot spots of the fire that in the territory of Leon, on the border with the autonomous community of Cantabria with the municipality of Camaleño.
In Cantabria are still activated with Level 2 of the Forest Fire Extinction Operative the Regions of: North Liébana, South Liébana, Nansa, Campoo, South Zone and Besaya.
Current situation of the Porto fire
The forest fire originated on August 14 by lightning in Porto has advanced in recent hours by the Sierra de la Cabrera, on the border between the provinces of Zamora and Leon, fanned by the wind that has made it has jumped the established defenses, as reported by the Fire Fighting Service of the Junta de Castilla y León.
Winds with constant gusts of 40 kilometers per hour have conditioned the advance of the fire this Monday afternoon that, after overcoming the defenses, the front has reached the summit that separates the two provinces and has forced to evacuate five Zamoran populations, four of them already evacuated last week.
The work in the afternoon hours more complicated by the wind, with gusts of up to 60 kilometers per hour, has consisted of containing the fire with the intention of waiting for an opportunity during the night.
The area of La Cabrera in León and Zamora, where the fire is advancing, is formed by a series of north-facing valleys.south where, aided by the westerly winds, the fire can advance with speed, explained sources of the firefighting operation.
It is also a very rocky area where the bulldozers can not work easily, so the strategy tonight is focused on making small backfires that help to gradually close small parts of the fire, according to these sources.
Mobilization of troops
A dozen ground crews, along with eight fire engines and two machinery retentions have worked last night with backfires and perimetration of the terrain in the forest fire of Porto (Zamora), which has been complicated by the wind on Monday afternoon and that keeps six evicted populations.
In the work of extinction at night, to which from 8.30 in the morning aerial means are added, have also worked five technicians and ten environmental agents, in addition to five external teams of urban firefighters, as reported by sources of operational extinction.
The work is focused on the environment of the Sierra de la Cabrera, which marks the boundary between the provinces of Zamora and León, where on Monday the fire, fanned by the wind, jumped the established defenses.
Roads cut off
Likewise, the fires have cut a total of nine road sections: the LE-5330 between Igüeña and Colinas; LE-7311, between Nogar and Castrillo de Cabrera; LE-4212, between Cariseda and Chano; LE-5228, between the towns of Bouzas and Corporales; LE-126, between La Baña, Mora de Luna and Sagüera de Luna (in crescent direction) and the LE-4523, between Otero de las Dueñas and Piedrasecha.
These are joined by the LE-4503, between Vega de Caballeros and Portilla de Luna, and the CL-626, in a stretch of 11 kilometers between Los Barrios de Luna and Otero de las Dueñas, and the ascent to the Morredero pass.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y623-RS92-21PN-00000-00SJM: Gas leak caused fire that consumed house and left one injured in Pamplona Alta2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisSJM: Gas leak caused fire that consumed house and left one injured in Pamplona Alta


A fire of great magnitude completely consumed a house in which also operated a laundry in the area of Pamplona Alta, district of San Juan de Miraflores.
The fire occurred on Los Sauces avenue, a few meters from the intersection with Salvador Allende avenue.


According to the owner of the house, Isabel Cruz, the fire originated after a gas leak during the installation of a balloon. She recounted the difficult moments she lived through with her family.
"My husband was installing the gas ball. I ran when I saw that it caught fire, I ran to wet a rag or something. But I threw the rag away and did not open the pipe, and I went out to get my son out of the cabin. And the fire was already there at our door, all our things (have burned): appliances, washing machine, dryer, stove, everything was damaged. There is nothing," she told RPP.
Cruz's husband was burned on his face as a result of the fire and was taken to a nearby health facility for medical attention.
Several firefighting companies rushed to the area and managed to control the flames, preventing the fire from spreading to other adjoining houses. However, the affected house was completely destroyed, leaving the family without material goods.
After the emergency, the victims requested support from the local authorities and the community, since they have lost practically all their belongings.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y603-RS3T-S2XP-00000-00Martha Moyano demands that judges apply Amnesty Law without objections2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisMartha Moyano demands that judges apply Amnesty Law without objections


Congresswoman Martha Moyano said that the Judiciary is obliged to apply the Amnesty Law approved by Congress and warned that magistrates who refuse to comply with it would be guilty of prevarication.


"The amnesty is an exclusive decision of the Congress, and the judges cannot go against this law", she said.
As she explained, there are defendants who have been facing judicial proceedings for more than two decades, so the measure seeks to provide a definitive solution to these cases.
Moyano considered that the discrepancies that have arisen regarding the application of the amnesty reflect the need to accelerate a judicial reform. In his opinion, the contradictory rulings of the judges on this matter generate a scenario of legal insecurity that must be resolved quickly.
In this line, she insisted that Congress has the power to legislate on amnesties and that it is up to the Judicial Power to limit itself to their execution.
The congresswoman also pronounced herself on the decision of the National Justice Board (JNJ) regarding the National Prosecutor, Delia Espinoza. In her opinion, the determinations of the JNJ must be followed, even in those cases that generate controversy.
Regarding Espinoza's performance, Moyano remarked that a thorough evaluation should be carried out, particularly in view of the debate on whether the reinstatement of the suspended prosecutor Patricia Benavides should be resolved by the JNJ or by the Board of Supreme Prosecutors.
Finally, Moyano reiterated that this context evidences the urgency of a structural change in the justice system.

urn:contentItem:6G2S-6G83-RRSC-3303-00000-00Research in the Area of Climate Change Reported from Korea University [Projecting Forest Fire Probability in South Korea Under Climate Change, Population, and Forest Management Scenarios Using AI & Process-Based Hybrid Model (FLAM-Net)]2025-06-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEResearch in the Area of Climate Change Reported from Korea University [Projecting Forest Fire Probability in South Korea Under Climate Change, Population, and Forest Management Scenarios Using AI & Process-Based Hybrid Model (FLAM-Net)]


2025 JUN 18 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on climate change. According to news originating from Seoul, South Korea, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Climate change-induced heat waves and densely forested areas near urban centers in South Korea create complex challenges for wildfire response systems. Various forest fire models have been developed to address this, each with unique strengths and weaknesses."


Funders for this research include Core Research Institute Basic Science Research Program; National Research Foundation of Korea; Ministry of Education; Forest Science Technology; Korea Forest Service; Korea Forestry Promotion Institute.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Korea University: "Process-based models offer high interpretability through human domain knowledge but require extensive optimization, while machine learning models automatically identify important features but have limited interpretability. To leverage the strengths of both models, this study aimed to integrate human domain knowledge into a machine learning framework. IIASA's wildfire cLimate impacts and Adaptation Model (FLAM)-a process-based model incorporating biophysical and human impacts-was developed as a neural network called FLAM-Net. Enhancements included improving backpropagation for optimization and introducing algorithms for national-specific fire ignition dynamics. FLAM-Net was applied at multiple scales and integrated through U-Net-based architecture, named deep neural FLAM (DN-FLAM), to produce downscaled predictions. The optimization revealed spatial concentration of fires near metropolitan areas and the east coast, with temporal concentration in spring due to agricultural burning. Integration of multiscale features through DN-FLAM achieved optimal performance with Pearson's r values of 0.943, 0.840, and 0.641 for temporal, spatial, and spatio-temporal validations. Future projections based on shared socioeconomic pathways indicated increasing fire frequencies until 2050, followed by a decrease due to increased precipitation."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study demonstrates the benefits of the hybrid approach, providing interpretability, accuracy, and efficient optimization. These hybrid models offer scientific evidence to guide locally tailored decision-making for climate change-induced forest fires and lay the groundwork for global application through their optimization capabilities."
For more information on this research see: Projecting Forest Fire Probability in South Korea Under Climate Change, Population, and Forest Management Scenarios Using AI & Process-Based Hybrid Model (FLAM-Net). IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing, 2025,18():13003-13022. The publisher for IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing is IEEE.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1109/JSTARS.2025.3564852.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Hyun-Woo Jo, OJEong Resilience Institute, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea. Additional authors for this research include Myoungsoo Won, Florian Kraxner, Seong Woo Jeon, Yowhan Son, Andrey Krasovskiy, Woo-Kyun Lee.

urn:contentItem:6GNM-G123-RT03-P27W-00000-00Consultant presents Houston climate action plan to council2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisConsultant presents Houston climate action plan to council

The District of Houston is continuing its work to create a Climate Action and Adaptation Plan.

At the Sept. 2 regular meeting of council, Pinna Sustainability introduced the Houston Climate Action and Adaptation Plan.

The meeting discussed the Climate Action and Adaptation Plan for Houston, focusing on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and building resilience.

The District retained Pinna Sustainability in May 2025 to lead the development of the plan for the District of Houston. They started working on it in June 2025 and have now completed phases one and two.

The plan, developed in four phases, aims to align with existing policies and set new goals.

Houston's GHG emissions increased by 29 per cent from 2007 to 2022, with transportation and buildings being major contributors.

Key climate hazards identified include wildfire, smoke, drought, and extreme heat. The plan includes strategies for active transportation, electric vehicles, and emergency response for vulnerable populations.

"The next steps currently for phase 3 and 4 are to start to develop emission reduction targets as outlined with the BC government as well as engage with various groups to start to develop goals and actionable lists of project which can support the mitigation and adaptation plans through the climate action plan," said the District's project manager Scott Sanders.

"We hope to have a reasonable list of short-, medium- and long-term project opportunities identified around the District which will support these efforts in climate action. These can be forest fire prevention, flood mitigation, GHG reduction through district-owned properties, as examples."

The next steps also involve further public engagement and finalizing the plan by January 2026.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2D53-RRPK-93HX-00000-00Latest Copernicus update lowers August burned hectares to 336,345 hectares2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisLatest Copernicus update lowers August burned hectares to 336,345 hectares


Forest fires have burned a total of 336,345 hectares across Spain during August, according to data from the European Commission's European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) from Copernicus as of August 31.


This figure is 7 percent lower than the latest data provided, which estimated that between August 1 and 21 had burned 362,473 hectares, due to adjustments of satellite information that is being received with data with better resolution.
This was announced this Friday by the third vice-president and minister for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge, Sara Aagesen, during her appearance in the Commission of Ecological Transition in the Congress of Deputies.
The main changes affect especially those autonomous communities that on August 21, the last information officially supplied by the Ministry, still had active forest fires.
By autonomous community, the largest area affected was in Galicia, with 143,628 hectares, 43%; Castilla y León, 141,264 hectares, 42%, and Extremadura, 41,525 hectares, 12%.
These three communities account for 97% of the area affected in August. The remaining 10,000 hectares are distributed in the rest of the communities with some fire episode during August.
Very high risk of fires
On the other hand, Aagesen has launched a message of caution by warning that "the emergency with respect to forest fires has not passed", despite the fact that the last episode of large fires has come to an end.
As indicated by the minister with sources from the Meteorological Agency (AEMET), the risk of fire is still "very high or extreme" in large areas of the country. In particular, the danger persists in areas of Castilla-La Mancha, Andalusia, Murcia, Alicante, in mountain areas of Cantabria and in the central Iberian system.

urn:contentItem:6H04-CSB3-RWN5-C1VB-00000-00PEDRO SNCHEZ CALLS FOR UNITY TO "FORGE A STATE PACT TO ADDRESS THE CLIMATE EMERGENCY," WHICH IS "TO FORGE A PACT FOR SPAIN"2025-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisPEDRO SNCHEZ CALLS FOR UNITY TO "FORGE A STATE PACT TO ADDRESS THE CLIMATE EMERGENCY," WHICH IS "TO FORGE A PACT FOR SPAIN"States News ServiceMADRID, Spain

The following information was released by the President of the Government of Spain:

The President of the Government of Spain stresses that the IMF joins other organisations "that applaud the economic strength of Spain," which "has become the driving force of economic growth and job creation throughout Europe."

The President of the Government of Spain, Pedro Snchez, has called for unity in order to "forge a State Pact to address the Climate Emergency", which "is to forge a Pact for Spain". In his speech at the Convention for a State Pact on the Climate Emergency, which is being held in Ponferrada, Snchez called for "making this State Pact a new example of unity, as we did with terrorism, pensions and gender violence".

"Spain is today at the forefront in the fight against climate change", he said, because "we chose to face this challenge head on, out of responsibility", but also "because we were able to see the ecological transition as an opportunity". The head of the Executive, who was accompanied by the Third Vice-President of the Government of Spain and Minister for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge, Sara Aagesen Muoz, and the government delegate in Castilla y Len, Nicanor Sen, pointed out that the priority is to tackle the climate emergency with a state vision and a long-term perspective.

"Tackling the climate emergency is about survival", because "climate change kills", as happened a year ago in the DANA in Valencia, but "it also impoverishes" because it increases inequality.

Appeal to administrations

The President of the Government of Spain addressed all the public administrations of our country, autonomous communities, provincial councils, town councils and municipalities, as well as all the political forces, "especially the PP", with an "outstretched hand" to regional presidents, mayors and public officials.

The President of the Government of Spain, Pedro Snchez, along with Third Vice-President and Minister for Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge, Sara Aagensen, at the Convention for a State Pact to Address the Climate Emergency | Pool Moncloa/Fernando Calvo

"The verdict of science is resounding, it is not possible to turn a blind eye and look the other way", demanded Snchez, who recalled that "the Government of Spain has not done so and never will".

He reaffirmed that "in the face of the effects of climate change, anticipation is essential, because not only mitigation, but also early adaptation is less costly and more effective than doing so reactively when impacts occur."

A government that acts

"That is why we declared a climate emergency in 2020, promoted the National Integrated Energy and Climate Plan or the National Plan for Adaptation to Climate Change, and also the first Climate Change and Energy Transition Law", the President of the Government of Spain explained. "And that is why we are allocating four out of every ten euros of the Recovery Plan to ecological transition and climate change mitigation," he added.

In addition, since 2017, the government has increased public investment in ecological transition, exceeding 30 billion. Today Spain is a world power in renewables, the fourth most sustainable large economy on the planet.

Citizen support for the State Pact

The President of the Government of Spain, Pedro Snchez, and the Third Vice-President and Minister for Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge, Sara Aagensen, with members of the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades | Pool Moncloa/Fernando Calvo

"To those who ignore the mandate out of pure sectarianism, I ask them to listen to the clamour of the Spanish people", said the President of the Government of Spain, referring to the public's support for the State Pact as reflected in the opinion polls.

Almost 90% of citizens consider climate change to be a serious problem and three out of four Spaniards are calling for a State Pact on the climate emergency. Nine out of ten also believe that we need to strengthen human and material resources to deal with fires and disasters.

Spain is the driving force of economic growth and job creation throughout Europe

Snchez used his speech to highlight that the IMF joins other organisations that "applaud the economic strength of Spain", which "has become the driving force of economic growth and job creation throughout Europe". In this regard, he stressed that the most important thing is that "we do it not by exploiting workers, nor by burning fossil fuels, but by creating more and better jobs, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and reducing the price of electricity by 50% thanks to the promotion of renewable energies".

"We are growing three times faster than the European average, we are breaking employment records, real wages have risen 6% above inflation in the last five years, and poverty and inequality are at historic lows. This time there is no trap and no bubble: what we have are good policies and that is a success for the country," he concluded.

urn:contentItem:6GJ4-9SH3-RSVF-J1FH-00000-00Spain endures one of its most destructive wildfire seasons2025-08-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisMAIN NEWSForeign DeskPart APg. 1Spain endures one of its most destructive wildfire seasonsNaishadham writes for the Associated Press. MADRID

Spain tackled several major wildfires on Tuesday in one of the country's most destructive fire seasons in recent decades, despite temperatures dropping across the Iberian Peninsula.

Thousands of firefighters aided by soldiers and water-bombing aircraft fought fires tearing through parched woodland that were especially severe in northwestern Spain, where the country's weather agency AEMET reported a still "very high or extreme" fire risk -- particularly in the Galicia region.

The fires in Galicia have ravaged small, sparsely populated towns, forcing locals in many cases to step in before firefighters arrive.

Firefighting units from Germany arrived in northern Spain on Tuesday to help fight the blazes, Spain's Interior Ministry announced. More than 20 vehicles were deployed to help fight an ongoing blaze in Jarilla in the Extremadura region that borders Portugal, the ministry said.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez visited the area Tuesday, where he spoke of the recent heat that has fueled the fires. Temperatures across the Iberian Peninsula dropped by about 7 degrees on Tuesday after a 16-day heat wave with several days above 104 degrees, Spain's weather agency reported.

"Science tells us, common sense tells us too, especially that of farmers and ranchers, of those who live in rural areas, that the climate is changing, that the climate emergency is becoming more and more recurrent, more frequent and has an ever greater impact," Sanchez said.

In Galicia, land management has also played a role; large stretches of unmanaged vegetation and depopulated villages in forested land have led to the build-up of wildfire fuel, said Adrian Regos, an ecologist at the Biological Mission of Galicia, a research institute.

The fires in Spain have killed four people this year and burned about 1,475 square miles, according to the European Union's European Forest Fire Information System. That surface area is more than twice the size of metropolitan London, more than six times the 2006-2024 average for land burned during the same period, according to EFFIS.

Air quality deteriorated across large parts of Spain over the last week as a result of the wildfires, data from the EU's Copernicus climate monitoring agency showed. Smoke from the Iberian Peninsula fires reached France, the United Kingdom and Scandinavia, it said.

Several fires have been triggered by human activity. Police have detained 23 people for suspected arson and are investigating 89 more, Spain's Civil Guard said Tuesday.

In Portugal, more than 3,700 firefighters were tackling blazes.

Wildfires there have burned about 907 square miles, according to EFFIS -- nearly five times more than the 2006-2024 average for this period. Two people there have died.

Europe has been warming twice as fast as the global average since the 1980s, according to Copernicus. Scientists say that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and intensity of heat and dryness in parts of Europe, making the region more vulnerable to wildfires.

PHOTO: A MEMBER of the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades battles a blaze in Castrelo do Val, Spain, on Tuesday. PHOTOGRAPHER:Pablo Blazquez Dominguez Getty Images

urn:contentItem:6GS8-7373-RSSH-V55G-00000-00J&K Assembly committee reviews forest conservation measures2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisJ&K Assembly committee reviews forest conservation measuresSrinagar

Srinagar, Sept. 18 -- The House Committee on Estimates today convened a meeting at the Assembly Complex, Srinagar, to review the functioning of the Jammu and Kashmir Forest, Ecology & Environment Department. The meeting was chaired by Committee Chairperson Shamim Firdous and attended by members including Abdul Majid Bhat Larmi, Ghulam Mohi-ud-Din Mir, Pawan Kumar Gupta, Gharu Ram Bhagat, Aijaz Ahmad Jan, Shafi Ahmad Wani, Chander Prakash Ganga, Pyare Lal Sharma, and Arjun Singh Raju.

Expressing serious concern over the dwindling forest area and its adverse impact on the environment, the Chairperson stressed the need for sustainable and time-bound measures to protect forests and safeguard ecological balance.The Committee emphasized conducting massive and sustained plantation drives across all regions of J&K.She impressed upon taking tangible steps to curb deforestation and prevent forest fire incidents.The Committee undertook a detailed review of initiatives taken to contain deforestation caused by various developmental projects under PMGSY, PWD, Rural Road Mission, National Highways Authority of India, and hydro-electric projects and measures taken for compensating falling of trees.She instructed that compensation of forest land use by user agency be also addressed on priority and details on the same be submitted to the Committee within 15 days time period.The Chairperson stressed that concrete initiatives be taken for re-plantation on priority, especially in tourist resorts such as Gulmarg, Yusmarg, Sonmarg, and Pahalgam, and sought details of deteriorated and fallen trees in these areas. She also called for strict measures to check the smuggling of pine and deodar trees.Members raised the issue of shortage in timber supply and directed that vacant and fallen timber be recovered immediately and distributed through timber depots.The Chairperson emphasized that the department should pick up many areas to developed them as green city areas, with planting variety of trees and also steps be taken to preserve our water body for sustainability of flora and fauna.The members raised issues of man- animal conflict and asserted that sterilization drives be taken to control the rising monkey population in Jammu areas, causing damage to crops and orchards.Senior officers present in the meeting included Commissioner Secretary, Forest Department, Sheetal Nanda; PCCF, J&K, Suresh K. Gupta; CWLW, Suresh Rai; MD FDCL, Suneesh Buxy; DG Budget Finance, M.S. Malik; Special Secretaries and other senior officers.

urn:contentItem:6GKN-6P73-RS19-N08T-00000-00Calgary researchers develop 'smelling' sensors inspired by insects2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisCANADA NEWSCalgary researchers develop 'smelling' sensors inspired by insects

Open a bottle of wine or peel a banana next to a window, and often, you'll notice a fruit fly buzzing around within minutes, the insect tracking scent from far away.

"As [insects] are flying, they always are looking for locations where the [scent] concentration is higher. The concentration goes up, so they go in the direction of the higher concentration," explained Arindam Phani, research associate at the University of Calgary.

It's the same principle that inspired him and his team to create a sensor that detects airborne molecules down to just 100 parts per billion - a thousand times more sensitive than a human nose.

In a recent study published in the journal Nano Letters, Phani and his team tested the sensor with various gases to see how it would react. The sensor was able to successfully detect organic compounds in the air at very low concentrations.

Sam Kim, an author on the study and professor in the Schulich School of Engineering, said the challenge of creating a novel sensor like this is making it both "sensitive" and "selective" to molecules.

The small sensor, made of a vibrating quartz crystal coated in a thin layer of porous material called a metal-organic framework, is an example of nanoscale technology. 

It's an innovative approach to a chemical sensor that Kim says "doesn't follow our conventional intuition." 

While traditional sensors struggle to differentiate molecules that have similar properties, Phani and his team's sensor was able to recognize each gas individually in the study.

One of the first applications of this technology, Phani imagines, would be in health care to improve breath analysis and possibly help detect diseases like cancers or diabetes with more precision.

"Our breath has a lot of information," he said, with hundreds of low concentration molecules present. "A mixture of all these different kinds of molecules gives you an idea about your health.

"If we can go down to [the] level of parts per billion to less than parts per trillion... that gives us a way to go into [a] new generation of breath analysis," far more advanced than a breathalyzer test one would take for alcohol detection, for example.

With the technology proving to work, the next step, Phani said, is for professionals like biologists and doctors to research how they can apply this sensor nanotechnology and put it to use. 

"If you can give us a very clear biomarker from our breath, definitely, we can develop a sensor for that and we can target it," Phani said.

Detecting forest fires is another application Phani suggests, as early indicators like nitrogen oxides are present in the air in low concentrations at the start of a fire.

"There is a possibility we can design sensors specifically catered for forest fire detection. And if you can do it quickly when the forest fire starts... it will be much easier to, maybe, control."

Committing to the insect inspiration, Phani also suggested the sensor could be attached onto a drone, allowing someone to fly it around and gather data for a 3D-concentration map. This concept could be used to identify where a gas leakage is along a pipeline, for example.

Once these kinds of applications are further researched and planned, the sensor itself can be manufactured at scale, keeping costs relatively low, Phani said.

At the moment, a basic sensor costs $25 to produce, he said, and the price tag goes up from there depending on its exact function and sophistication.

But Phani is hopeful that once these sensors move to a production stage, costs can be brought down further.

urn:contentItem:6FBP-K443-RRR7-Y02K-00000-00MONMOUTH COUNTY HOSTS FOREST FIRE INFORMATION SESSION AT HUBER WOODS PARK2025-03-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisMONMOUTH COUNTY HOSTS FOREST FIRE INFORMATION SESSION AT HUBER WOODS PARK

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., March 13 -- Monmouth County issued the following press release:

The Monmouth County Board of County Commissioners hosted a forest fire information session at Huber Woods Park with presentations from the Monmouth County Fire Marshal's Office, the Monmouth County Park System, the New Jersey Forest Fire Service and the Middletown Fire Department to discuss measures taken during a forest fire on March 6.

"I would like to thank the Monmouth County Fire Marshal's Office, the Monmouth County Park System, the New Jersey Forest Fire Service and the Middletown Fire Department for joining us for our presentation about forest fires," said Commissioner Director Thomas A. Arnone. "Approximately 25 residents from the neighborhoods surrounding Huber Woods and Hartshorne Woods parks were in attendance for this presentation and we thank them for taking the time to attend."

"During the presentation, fire officials described the firefighting resources that would be deployed in the event of a forest fire in the area," said Commissioner Dominick "Nick" DiRocco, liaison to the Monmouth County Fire Marshal. "Our County Fire Marshal, Fred Migliaccio, explained the various firefighting task forces, comprised of Monmouth County municipal fire departments, that would be deployed in the event of a fire in the area. He also explained the various measures homeowners can take to reduce the risk of fires spreading to their properties."

"During the session, Assistant County Park Superintendent Rick Royle explained that park rangers regularly maintain trails and tend to fallen trees," said Commissioner Ross F. Licitra, liaison to the Monmouth County Park System. "A Park System ecologist detailed measures that have been taken by the County to improve the health of the woodlands to encourage the growth of native plants and trees, reduce natural debris that fuels fires and improve access for firefighting equipment." urn:contentItem:6GJD-F303-RRH6-F51C-00000-00Britain to pay nearly $4 million in compensation after troops sparked huge forest fire while training in Kenya2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisBritain to pay nearly $4 million in compensation after troops sparked huge forest fire while training in KenyaBy Larry Madowo, CNN(CNN)

(CNN) - The British government has agreed to pay almost $4 million to thousands of victims of a blaze started by its soldiers while in training in Kenya, according to documents seen by CNN.

The settlement follows a long legal battle by local community members in the East African country. The campaigners have said the effects of the 2021 fire in an expansive wildlife conservancy in central Kenya have caused them lifelong health issues, damaged their property and polluted their environment.

Some of them also told CNN that they lost family members due to ailments arising from the inferno that burned through more than 10,000 acres in the privately owned Lolldaiga conservancy.

The fire is believed to have started accidentally during a British military training exercise. The British Army Training Unit Kenya (BATUK) posted a video at the time showing its officers battling the blaze, in which it claimed the community and wildlife had been kept safe.

The government of the United Kingdom has now agreed to pay £2.9 million (about $3.9 million) to 7,723 Kenyans who filed complaints, but will not accept liability for the fire, according to a confidential settlement agreement obtained by CNN.

The settlement is not being shared equally. Many beneficiaries were disappointed that, after the four-year legal fight, they will receive just 22,000 Kenyan shillings ($170) and now plan to protest, according to a local lawmaker.

"It's a success story because it's the first time we've ever won a case against the British Army in Kenya but it's so little it's almost nothing," Laikipia County MP Cate Waruguru told CNN. "They feel that their sweat and their struggle have not borne any fruit. We need to see our courts stand up to protect the rights of Kenyans," she added.

Kelvin Kubai, a 27-year-old lawyer who grew up in the area, initiated the class-action lawsuit that culminated in the settlement, although he said his clients had hoped for a payout some 20 times larger.

"Military training and conservation are incompatible. There is a need to separate them," Kubai told CNN on Thursday. "This payment is nowhere close to give (my clients)... the financial assistance to enable them to move far away from this training. So the only thing now is to move the training away from them." He says the "ex gratia" payout - a voluntary payment made outside of any legal obligation - was the fastest way to compensate the affected community instead of pushing for a full trial that could have lasted years.

The British army pays Kenya about $400,000 a year to allow BATUK to train in the country. The UK troops operate mostly in large wildlife conservancies in Laikipia and the neighboring Samburu County. But allegations of human rights abuses including rape and murder have dogged BATUK for decades, leading to an ongoing Kenyan parliamentary investigation. Military officials say they investigate all reported claims of misconduct against officers in Kenya, but they do not comment on individual cases.

The British High Commission in Nairobi, which represents BATUK in country, said it was "pleased that a global settlement has been agreed with the claimants' appointed legal representatives" and called the fire "extremely regrettable" but declined to say if any officers had faced disciplinary action for it.

"The UK has devoted considerable time, effort and resource to resolving these claims for the people affected," a spokesperson told CNN in a statement.

CNN has also contacted the British Ministry of Defence for comment.

'If we get this money, we will leave'

Community members have previously demonstrated against BATUK and the British government. When CNN met a group of area residents outside the fence of the Lolldaiga conservancy in June last year, many hoped for a substantial payout so that they could move away from the area.

One woman raised her inhaler above her head as she explained that she and most of her neighbors had developed breathing difficulties requiring medication and frequent hospital visits following the fire.

Nearby, Hannah Wanjiku fought back tears as she spoke of the British troops who train near her home. She said that her grandchildren are sick and that she has developed chest problems. "We live a difficult life. If we get this money, we will leave," Wanjiku added.

The community meeting in June 2024 was convened by activist James Mwangi who has campaigned for the residents since the blaze. "In March 2021, this area was a furnace for seven days. Over 10,000 people were choked by smoke, toxic smoke," he told CNN at the time.

In environmental terms, one report, by consultancy firm Howard Humphreys - commissioned by Lolldaiga Hills Limited - found it would take until at least 2060 for the land to fully recover from the effects of the fire.

Previously a private livestock ranch, Lolldaiga became a conservancy in 2021 and is home to the endangered Grevy's zebra, elephants, buffaloes, lions, hyenas, jackals, vervet monkeys and baboons.

By Larry Madowo, CNN

urn:contentItem:6GKK-JFP3-RS09-73CR-00000-00Spain to grant aid for wildfire-hit catastrophe zones2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSSpain to grant aid for wildfire-hit catastrophe zonesHuang Yan,Paul Giblin

MADRID, Aug. 26 (Xinhua) -- The Spanish government on Tuesday declared areas affected by wildfires as catastrophe zones, allowing them to access emergency aid. Interior Minister Fernando Grande-Marlaska said at a press conference broadcast by national television channel RTVE that the measure applies to all regions affected by the 113 wildfires recorded between June 23 and Aug. 25. "We are facing one of the worst environmental crises in recent years," said Grande-Marlaska, adding that affected residents can apply for compensation. The aid also covers areas hit by severe flooding at the end of June. Government aid will include support for households, businesses and local authorities, as well as compensation for farmers whose crops, woodland and livestock were damaged. Additional measures include grants for infrastructure repairs and preferential credit lines. According to the European Forest Fire Information Service, wildfires in Spain have burned an estimated 418,000 hectares this summer, an area larger than the island of Mallorca. However, Grande-Marlaska said it is too early to give a final assessment of the damage. Fifteen wildfires remain active in northwestern Spain, mainly in the provinces of Zamora and Ourense. Despite lower temperatures in recent days, firefighting efforts continue to be hampered by strong winds. Enditem

urn:contentItem:6FMP-T303-RS77-518V-00000-00New Jersey forest fire prompts thousands of evacuations and closes a major highway2025-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSSTATE AND REGIONALNew Jersey forest fire prompts thousands of evacuations and closes a major highwayBARNEGAT TOWNSHIP, N.J.

BARNEGAT TOWNSHIP, N.J. — A fast-moving wildfire burning in New Jersey on Tuesday forced thousands of people to evacuate and closed a stretch of a major highway.

The Garden State Parkway, one of New Jersey's busiest highways, was closed between Barnegat and Lacey townships, according to the New Jersey Fire Service.

More than 1,300 structures were threatened and about 3,000 residents were evacuated, the fire service said. Shelters were open at two high schools, according to the Barnegat Police Department.

The Jersey Central Power and Light Company cut power to about 25,000 customers at the request of the Forest Fire Service and the wildfire’s command post Tuesday evening, including thousands in Barnegat Township. The company said on X that it doesn’t expect to restore the power before Wednesday.

“This is for the safety of crews battling the fire,” the company said.

The fire in the Greenwood Forest Wildlife Management Area burned more than 13.2 square miles (34.2 square kilometers) of land, fire officials said.

The blaze, burning in Ocean and Lacey Townships in Ocean County, was only about 10% contained Tuesday night, the New Jersey Fire Service said. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

There were no immediate reports of injuries.

Debi Schaffer was caught in gridlocked traffic after evacuating with her two dogs while her husband agreed to stay with their 22 chickens, The Press of Atlantic City reported.

“I wanted to take them in the car with me; can you imagine 22 chickens in a car?" she told the newspaper.

Around her Waretown house it was “like a war zone,” she said, describing smoke, sirens and the buzz of helicopters.

The site of the fire is near an alpaca farm. The farm said in a Facebook post that the property wasn’t threatened and all of the animals were safe.

The blaze is the second major forest fire in the region in less than a week.

urn:contentItem:6GPD-0433-RTWF-745N-00000-00No respect for speed limit on Ensenada- San Felipe highway2025-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisNo respect for speed limit on Ensenada- San Felipe highway


Ensenada BC.- Volunteer paramedics from the town of Héroes de la Independencia, reported the non-compliance of speed limits on the Ensenada San Felipe highway, mainly by some drivers of heavy trucks.


The highway passes through the middle of the ejido and there are trucks that go over 140 to 180 kilometers per hour, they are traveling exaggeratedly fast, not all of them, there are some that moderate their speed to 50 kilometers per hour, but most of them are going very fast and have been on the point of causing accidents".
José Valverde, volunteer paramedic, pointed out.
May be of interest: Ensenada to Ojos Negros highway closed due to forest fire
He explained that when the ejido residents want to take the highway, mainly the elderly, they are the ones who are most at risk, since, not having their vision at one hundred percent, they can be victims of accidents.
"It is assumed that on the highway when there is a village you go at low speed and the trucks have been on the verge of committing an accident," he warned.
Support from the authorities
The paramedic asked for the support of the authorities, as he fears that the excessive speed added to the terrible conditions of the road could provoke more accidents.
"I think it would be to the National Guard because it is a federal highway, that they supervise the road, apart from the fact that it is ugly with many holes and the tractor-trailers at full speed, the road is alone, there is no security, in the town there are policemen, but they have commented that they cannot do anything because it is a federal highway", he exposed.
José Valverde recalled that on the Ensenada-San Felipe highway, there are several towns with a lack of speed limit signs.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88F3-RX18-S2FW-00000-00The Spanish government estimates 393,279 hectares affected by fires in 20252025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisThe Spanish government estimates 393,279 hectares affected by fires in 2025


The Spanish government estimated this Friday that 393,278.99 hectares (ha) were affected by fires in 2025, up to the last 24th, most of them this August.


As published Friday by the Spanish Ministry for Ecological Transition on its website, these data for 2025 (393,278.99 hectares affected) exceed those of 2022 (253,251 hectares), which until now was considered the worst year in terms of area burned.
In addition, this year exceeded the average number of hectares burned in the last ten years, which stood at 79,882 ha since 2015, compared to 99,369 as of last August 24.
According to the ministry, so far this year, 53 large fires (over 500 ha) have been recorded in Spain, when the average since 2015 was at 17.
In relation to woody vegetation, 21,508.73 hectares of woodland burned, as well as 48,206.79 ha of scrubland and open woodland and 29,653 of pastures and meadows.
Last Tuesday, the Spanish Government approved the declaration of areas affected by climatic emergencies (fires and floods) in 16 of Spain's 17 regions and set in motion the procedure for those affected to apply for aid and subsidies.
For its estimates of hectares affected by fire this year, released today, the Ministry took into account the figures provided by the different regions and those estimated by the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

urn:contentItem:6GMP-6CN3-RXY1-V50M-00000-00Firefighters of Quito liquidated four fires this Sunday, August 312025-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisFirefighters of Quito liquidated four fires this Sunday, August 31


A forest fire in the sector of Guangopolo, in the vicinity of the Ilaló volcano, northeast of Quito was recorded this Sunday, August 31. The alert was received by ECU911 at 11:47 a.m. Personnel from the Quito Fire Department went to the site to contain the flames.


Authorities reported that constant monitoring is maintained. First responders remain in the area to protect the population and the natural environment.
For its part, the Quito Fire Department reported that it was a waste burning. This was attended in a timely manner. The incident was controlled and liquidated with a damage of at least 40 square meters.
The other three fires occurred in the Eternit Industrial Park, in Turubamba, south of Quito. Another scourge occurred in the Zámbiza ravine and in the sector of La Libertad, in Chillogallo. In the latter, registered at 13:33, the firefighters presume that the fire was caused by the manipulation of fire by minors, but it was controlled and liquidated.
Three active fires in three provinces
Additionally, throughout Ecuador, the National Secretariat of Risk Management reports the existence of three active fires. In Cañar, specifically, in the La Carbonería sector, firefighting tasks have been underway since August 27. The causes of this event are unknown.
The third active fire occurred this August 31 in Patate (Tungurahua), in the Poatug sector, on the hill on the road to Sucre.

urn:contentItem:6GNJ-XTC3-RYKR-5193-00000-00Cambodia Reaffirms Commitment to Tackle Environmental Challenges2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisCambodia Reaffirms Commitment to Tackle Environmental Challenges

04 Sep 2025 (Agence Kampuchea Presse) Cambodia is taking a strong stance in addressing regional and global environmental challenges, the nation's Minister of Environment, H.E. Dr. Eang Sophalleth, said on September 3.

Speaking at the 18th ASEAN Ministerial Meeting on the Environment (AMME-18) in Malaysia, Dr. Sophalleth highlighted several of Cambodia's key initiatives, including the adoption of the National Strategy on Resilient, Sustainable, and Inclusive Development and the Long-Term Strategy for Carbon Neutrality 2050.

The Ministry of Environment reported that these efforts include significant progress in plastic waste management, with more than half the population now embracing the 4Rs principles (Refuse, Reduce, Reuse, Recycle).

The country also plants over two million trees annually to combat deforestation and mitigate forest fire risks.

To enforce sustainability, the Royal Government has mandated that the private sector install wastewater treatment systems and adhere to strict environmental standards. These actions are designed to help Cambodia achieve its goal of carbon neutrality by 2050, with implementation guided by sectoral roadmaps and the first phase of the National Pentagon Strategy.

Dr. Sophalleth called on ASEAN member states to strengthen regional cooperation, particularly through institutions like the ASEAN Centre for Biodiversity. He also stressed the importance of regional solidarity ahead of COP30, which will be hosted in Brazil.

In a joint statement for COP30, Cambodia emphasized the critical role of climate finance and affordable green technologies in upcoming negotiations. "Without predictable resources, no member state can fully realize its commitments," the minister stated, urging ASEAN to present a united front to ensure the region's concerns are heard and respected on the global stage.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88C3-RWV2-G2CG-00000-00Minam: 16 native communities of Atalaya strengthen surveillance of their forests2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisMinam: 16 native communities of Atalaya strengthen surveillance of their forests

The workshops were aimed at the custodians of the Community Forest Surveillance and Control Committees of Ucayali - Atalaya, who play a key role as environmental defenders.
Read also: Pronabec: close to 10,000 Peruvians from border districts received scholarships for studies
The custodians received training on forestry legislation, environmental crimes, forest fire management, social and environmental safeguards, good forest harvesting practices, compensation mechanisms for fines and integrity in forest management.


Invited institutions such as the Ministry of Justice and Human Rights, SERFOR, OSINFOR, SOFFSA of the Regional Government of Ucayali, the Specialized Environmental Prosecutor's Office, the National Association of Communal Reserve Administration Contract Executors (ANECAP) and the El Sira Communal Reserve Administration Contract Executor (ECOSIRA) participated in this effort. One of the educational tools used was the "Forestry Backpack: Institutionalism and the Fight against Corruption," developed and delivered by OSINFOR and Proética.
In total, 126 people (93 men and 33 women) from native communities such as Catoteni, Cocani, Sheremashe, Pensilvania, among others in the El Sira Communal Reserve, strengthened their capacities to confront threats such as illegal logging, fires and corruption in the management of their resources.
With these workshops, Minam's Forest Program reaffirms its commitment to work together with indigenous peoples to ensure the conservation of the Amazon, the safety of forest custodians and compliance with conservation agreements.

urn:contentItem:6GS4-RN13-RRYK-N0M4-00000-00Committee on Estimates reviews functioning of Forest, Ecology & Environment Department2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisCommittee on Estimates reviews functioning of Forest, Ecology & Environment DepartmentSrinagar

Srinagar, Sept. 17 -- The House Committee on Estimates today convened a meeting at the Assembly Complex, Srinagar, to review the functioning of the Jammu and Kashmir Forest, Ecology & Environment Department. The meeting was chaired by Committee Chairperson Shamim Firdous and attended by members including Abdul Majid Bhat Larmi, Ghulam Mohi-ud-Din Mir, Pawan Kumar Gupta, Gharu Ram Bhagat, Aijaz Ahmad Jan, Shafi Ahmad Wani, Chander Prakash Ganga, Pyare Lal Sharma, and Arjun Singh Raju.

Expressing serious concern over the dwindling forest area and its adverse impact on the environment, the Chairperson stressed the need for sustainable and time-bound measures to protect forests and safeguard ecological balance. The Committee emphasized conducting massive and sustained plantation drives across all regions of J&K. She impressed upon taking tangible steps to curb deforestation and prevent forest fire incidents. The Committee undertook a detailed review of initiatives taken to contain deforestation caused by various developmental projects under PMGSY, PWD, Rural Road Mission, National Highways Authority of India, and hydro-electric projects and measures taken for compensating falling of trees. She instructed that compensation of forest land use by user agency be also addressed on priority and details on the same be submitted to the Committee within 15 days time period. The Chairperson stressed that concrete initiatives be taken for re-plantation on priority, especially in tourist resorts such as Gulmarg, Yusmarg, Sonmarg, and Pahalgam, and sought details of deteriorated and fallen trees in these areas. She also called for strict measures to check the smuggling of pine and deodar trees. Members raised the issue of shortage in timber supply and directed that vacant and fallen timber be recovered immediately and distributed through timber depots. The Chairperson emphasized that the department should pick up many areas to developed them as green city areas, with planting variety of trees and also steps be taken to preserve our water body for sustainability of flora and fauna. The members raised issues of man- animal conflict and asserted that sterilization drives be taken to control the rising monkey population in Jammu areas, causing damage to crops and orchards. Senior officers present in the meeting included Commissioner Secretary, Forest Department, Sheetal Nanda; PCCF, J&K, Suresh K. Gupta; CWLW, Suresh Rai; MD FDCL, Suneesh Buxy; DG Budget Finance, M.S. Malik; Special Secretaries and other senior officers.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-96P3-RT4F-V28K-00000-00Government deploys military patrols to protect Tunari National Park2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisGovernment deploys military patrols to protect Tunari National Park


After controlling the forest fires in Tunari National Park, the national government has decided that the Armed Forces (FFAA) will carry out continuous patrols. The objective of these actions is to prevent new outbreaks and protect the biodiversity of this important park.


Forest fire patrols
Since Sunday, a patrol of forest firefighters from the Bolivian Air Force (FAB) has been deployed. This patrol has been making daily patrols throughout the park. In the first two days of operation, 4 fires were identified, which, according to the report, had been set by unscrupulous people. As of today, there are no active fires in the area.
Positive control results
The authorities have described the results of the control as "highly positive". This evaluation has led the Minister of Defense, Edmundo Novillo, together with the Vice-Minister of Civil Defense, Juan Carlos Calvimontes, and the military high command, to decide to extend the scope of the operation.
Joint and sustained operation
Based on these results, it has been decided that the patrolling will not only be carried out by the Air Force. Instead, a joint and sustained operation between the 3 State forces will be implemented. The main objective of this strategy is to preserve our parks, as well as the flora and fauna of the region.
The post Government deploys military patrols to protect Tunari National Park first appeared on Periódico La Patria.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BP03-RSJC-S4B4-00000-00Unbelievable. Colmo: a man who was supposed to be a volunteer firefighter was arrested for starting a fire in a field in Córdoba.2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisUnbelievable. Colmo: a man who was supposed to be a volunteer firefighter was arrested for starting a fire in a field in Córdoba.


In an unusual event, at least due to the characteristics of one of the protagonists, two fishermen were arrested after starting a fire in an improper place, near a field close to provincial route 5, in the locality of Embalse, towards Segunda Usina.


The outstanding fact is that, according to the police, one of those arrested was a volunteer firefighter.
The incident occurred in a context in which the province of Córdoba is under a high fire risk alert.
The situation caused great uneasiness in the whole region of Calamuchita and took place in the morning of this Tuesday 26th.
The fire was detected by the firefighters of Embalse, by the police and by the owner of a nearby field. They all saw smoke coming out of a mountainous area and rushed to the place because of the risk of a forest fire.
It was unfortunate for the firefighters to find a colleague resting in the lake of fire and outrageous for the owner of the neighboring field. For the police, there was no contemplation: the two offenders were detained and are now at the disposal of the courts to resolve their situation.
The fire was surrounded by a stone fence. In the middle, there was the bonfire. However, nothing saves the firefighter involved from doing something that is forbidden by law, aggravated negligence due to his condition of firefighter.
The two detainees reportedly indicated that they lit a fire to heat the kettle for drinking mate.
The fire did not cause a fire. But the smoke caused an alert in a high-risk area.
Clarification from the firehouse
The Embalse Volunteer Fire Department informed that its personnel is now suspended.
The local Volunteer Firefighters Association issued a communiqué in which it expresses:
"The Volunteer Fire Department of Embalse wishes to inform the community of an event that occurred in the morning of today, involving a member of our institution.
In personal circumstances and out of service, the firefighter was on a fishing trip on the shore of the river with a friend, who lit a small fire on the shore.
It is essential to clarify to the community that at no time was there any intention to start a forest fire, nor to deliberately violate current regulations. It was a reckless behavior, originated in a recreational context, which nevertheless falls under the provisions of Article 91 of the Code of Citizen Coexistence of the Provincial Law in force 10.326, in the Province of Cordoba, which is why police personnel intervened and the corresponding proceedings were carried out, leaving it at the disposal of the corresponding administrative authority.
As an institution, we understand the seriousness of the legal and environmental framework in which we find ourselves, and therefore we have ordered the preventive suspension of the officer involved, in compliance with the provisions of the regulations of the Volunteer Firefighters of the Province of Córdoba, until the summary is substantiated and his administrative and/or judicial situation is defined as appropriate.
We reaffirm to society that the Embalse Volunteer Fire Department maintains an absolute commitment to fire prevention, unrestricted respect for the law and the protection of the environment. Likewise, we remind the importance of avoiding any kind of ignition, even with apparently harmless purposes, since every bonfire entails potential risks for our natural environment.
Our institution will continue to work with transparency, responsibility and adherence to regulations, as it has historically done, in order to care for the community and the natural resources that surround us".

urn:contentItem:6GJK-PJ33-RS54-84R2-00000-00PARLIAMENT QUESTION: SATELLITE DATA FOR AGRICULTURE, WATER RESOURCES AND DISASTER MANAGEMENT2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisPARLIAMENT QUESTION: SATELLITE DATA FOR AGRICULTURE, WATER RESOURCES AND DISASTER MANAGEMENT

India, Aug. 21 -- The Government of India issued the following news release:

Paddy crop mapping, Kharif sown area, weekly sowing & harvesting progress, drought monitoring; groundwater prospects, recharge plan and quality mapping at 1:50,000 scale; monitoring of water spread of waterbodies of size greater than 1 ha (8,368 no.); mapping of wetlands at 1:50,000 scale (2017-18 time frame) and at 1:12,500 scale (2018-19 time frame) were carried out for all 24 districts of Jharkhand.

Under the Disaster Management Support Programme (DMSP), Department of Space provides space-based products/ services to respective nodal Ministries / Departments and concerned State Disaster Management Authorities, including Jharkhand, for appropriate disaster management measures by them.

Specifically:

Flood inundation mapped during major floods every year using satellite data are provided to concerned nodal departments of the States for effective flood disaster management.

Flood Hazard Zonation atlases developed using historical satellite-derived flood data since 1998 for several major flood-prone States, such as Assam, Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal, Odisha, and Andhra Pradesh are disseminated to the respective States.

ISRO developed Spatial flood early warning systems for Godavari and Tapi Rivers as part of the National Hydrology Project are being run operationally by Ministry of Jal Shakti. Flood Early Warning System (FLEWS) is implemented for the flood affected districts of Assam and is being extended to other flood prone districts in the NER. Early warning from both these systems are provided to the concerned State departments.

Landslide Atlas of India comprising of geospatial landslide inventory database of ~80,000 landslides in India are mapped by NRSC/ ISRO during 1998-2022 period. The database covers landslide vulnerable regions in 17 States and 02 Union Territories of India, across the Himalaya and Western Ghats. This atlas is provided to State departments for necessary utilisation.

Active forest fires are detected using satellite data daily 6 to 8 times during the Indian forest fire season, every year. These inputs are provided to FSI/ MoEF&CC and to concerned State Departments for Forest Fire Management measures.

ISRO/DoS has carried out groundwater prospects and quality mapping on 1:50,000 scale, for entire country under the Jal Jeevan Mission (JJM) of National Rural Drinking Water Program (NRDWP), Ministry of Jal Shakti. The final deliverable in the form of groundwater prospects maps have been provided to state line department for identification of potential groundwater sources and sites suitable for artificial recharge structure. ISRO/DoS has trained around 150 officers of state line departments in utilizing the groundwater prospects maps for taking appropriate decision on the field.

ISRO provided eight geospatial layers each for 1240 Jal Shakti Abhiyan (JSA) blocks and also hosted these on ISRO's Bhuvan-JSA Geoportal. The maps provided by ISRO helped JSA field teams for identifying sites for various water conservation/ recharge interventions executed under JSA. About 50 technical sessions were organized for the JSA teams by ISRO towards explaining the use of above maps.

This information was given by Dr. Jitendra Singh, Union Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Science and Technology, Earth Sciences, MoS PMO, MoS Personnel, Public Grievances & Pensions, Department of Atomic Energy and Department of Space, in a written reply in the Rajya Sabha today.

urn:contentItem:6GJD-0D83-RT5Y-C4KD-00000-00PARLIAMENT QUESTION: SATELLITE DATA FOR AGRICULTURE, WATER RESOURCES AND DISASTER MANAGEMENT2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisPARLIAMENT QUESTION: SATELLITE DATA FOR AGRICULTURE, WATER RESOURCES AND DISASTER MANAGEMENTStates News ServiceNEW DELHI, India

The following information was released by the Government of India:

by PIB Delhi

Paddy crop mapping, Kharif sown area, weekly sowing and harvesting progress, drought monitoring; groundwater prospects, recharge plan and quality mapping at 1:50,000 scale; monitoring of water spread of waterbodies of size greater than 1 ha (8,368 no.); mapping of wetlands at 1:50,000 scale (2017-18 time frame) and at 1:12,500 scale (2018-19 time frame) were carried out for all 24 districts of Jharkhand.

Under the Disaster Management Support Programme (DMSP), Department of Space provides space-based products/ services to respective nodal Ministries / Departments and concerned State Disaster Management Authorities, including Jharkhand, for appropriate disaster management measures by them.

Specifically:

Flood inundation mapped during major floods every year using satellite data are provided to concerned nodal departments of the States for effective flood disaster management.

Flood Hazard Zonation atlases developed using historical satellite-derived flood data since 1998 for several major flood-prone States, such as Assam, Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal, Odisha, and Andhra Pradesh are disseminated to the respective States.

ISRO developed Spatial flood early warning systems for Godavari and Tapi Rivers as part of the National Hydrology Project are being run operationally by Ministry of Jal Shakti. Flood Early Warning System (FLEWS) is implemented for the flood affected districts of Assam and is being extended to other flood prone districts in the NER. Early warning from both these systems are provided to the concerned State departments.

Landslide Atlas of India comprising of geospatial landslide inventory database of ~80,000 landslides in India are mapped by NRSC/ ISRO during 1998-2022 period. The database covers landslide vulnerable regions in 17 States and 02 Union Territories of India, across the Himalaya and Western Ghats. This atlas is provided to State departments for necessary utilisation.

Active forest fires are detected using satellite data daily 6 to 8 times during the Indian forest fire season, every year. These inputs are provided to FSI/ MoEFandCC and to concerned State Departments for Forest Fire Management measures.

ISRO/DoS has carried out groundwater prospects and quality mapping on 1:50,000 scale, for entire country under the Jal Jeevan Mission (JJM) of National Rural Drinking Water Program (NRDWP), Ministry of Jal Shakti. The final deliverable in the form of groundwater prospects maps have been provided to state line department for identification of potential groundwater sources and sites suitable for artificial recharge structure. ISRO/DoS has trained around 150 officers of state line departments in utilizing the groundwater prospects maps for taking appropriate decision on the field.

ISRO provided eight geospatial layers each for 1240 Jal Shakti Abhiyan (JSA) blocks and also hosted these on ISROs Bhuvan-JSA Geoportal. The maps provided by ISRO helped JSA field teams for identifying sites for various water conservation/ recharge interventions executed under JSA. About 50 technical sessions were organized for the JSA teams by ISRO towards explaining the use of above maps.

This information was given by Dr. Jitendra Singh, Union Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Science and Technology, Earth Sciences, MoS PMO, MoS Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions, Department of Atomic Energy and Department of Space, in a written reply in the Rajya Sabha today.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DGK3-RS3M-F42N-00000-00Spain suffered this month the most intense heat wave in its history2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisSpain suffered this month the most intense heat wave in its history


Madrid (Xinhua) - Spain's State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) reported that the heat wave that hit the country this August was the most intense on record, both in terms of temperatures and impacts.


According to provisional data, average temperatures from August 3 to 18 exceeded the seasonal average by 4.6 degrees Celsius, thus surpassing the previous record of 4.5 degrees Celsius set in July 2022.
The AEMET noted that August 8-17 saw the 10 warmest consecutive days since at least 1950, while the first 20 days of August were the warmest for that period since at least 1961.
August 11, 16 and 17 were among the 10 hottest days recorded in Spain since 1941 and, since records began in 1975, Spain experienced 77 heat waves.
According to the government's Daily Mortality Monitoring System, this year's heat waves caused 1,149 deaths. In addition, the extreme heat coincided with the worst month of forest fires on record in Spain.
Data from the European Forest Fire Information System show that 406,100 hectares of land burned, about 5.5 times the size of Singapore.
The fires caused four deaths and forced the evacuation of more than 30,000 people, most of whom returned to their homes, although many wildfires were still active as of Sunday.

urn:contentItem:6GRG-9T13-S0GH-P2JD-00000-00Army Chinook helicopters to be evaluated for firefighting readiness2025-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:56ZLexisNexisArmy Chinook helicopters to be evaluated for firefighting readiness


The capacity of a single helicopter to discharge 7,600 liters of water on a forest fire could change the rules of the game in firefighting in Spain. That is the proposal being considered for the Army's giant Chinooks, an idea that would represent a giant leap forward compared to current means. The difference is abysmal when compared to the Cougar helicopters currently used by the Air Mobile Forces (Famet), whose load capacity is limited to 1,800 liters.


In fact, this initiative would completely transform the work of the Transport Helicopter Battalion V (Bheltra V), based in Colmenar Viejo (Madrid). These aircraft, the backbone of the Armed Forces' heavy transport, have never participated in firefighting missions. Their conversion would imply a change in their main mission, from transporting troops and material to becoming a shock force against the flames, an unprecedented role for them. This idea of adapting transport aircraft for new roles is a growing trend in the defense field, similar to that of multipurpose capabilities.
However, the project runs up against an obstacle that is neither technical nor economic, but purely organizational. The real wall to overcome, according to , is the enormous logistical challenge that deployment would entail. Feasibility depends on a major restructuring that would require expanding the workforce with specialized personnel, intensifying training and adapting the entire support chain.
The hidden costs of new capacity
In addition to the organizational complexity, there is also the investment required. Although not the main constraint, the acquisition of helibuckets, popularly known as "Bambi Buckets", represents a considerable financial outlay. The price of each of these unloading devices ranges from 50,000 to 70,000 euros, a figure that must be taken into account in any budget planning. This outlay is in addition to other budgetary requirements for the modernization of the Armed Forces, as, for example, the to avoid becoming obsolete.
Likewise, while this ambitious transformation is being studied, the Army is not standing still and is already working on reinforcing existing resources. Regardless of the final decision on the Chinooks, short-term plans include increasing the fleet of Cougar helicopters dedicated to firefighting from the current three aircraft to a total of five in order to strengthen their support to civil society.
